cn.name: source_span.FileLocation

methods.name: pointSpan
methods.desc: Returns a span that covers only a single point: this location.
methods.example:
Implementation

FileSpan pointSpan() => new _FileSpan(file, offset, offset);

props.name: column
props.desc: The 0-based column of this location in the source

props.name: file
props.desc: The file that this belongs to.

props.name: line
props.desc: The 0-based line of this location in the source.

props.name: offset
props.desc: The 0-based offset of this location in the source.

props.name: sourceUrl
props.desc:
URL of the source containing this location.

This may be null, indicating that the source URL is unknown or unavailable.

cn.desc:
A SourceLocation within a SourceFile.

Unlike the base SourceLocation, FileLocation lazily computes its line and column values based on its offset and the contents of file.

A FileLocation can be created using SourceFile.location.

cn.name: source_span.FileSpan

methods.name: expand
methods.desc:
Returns a new span that covers both this and other.

Unlike union, other may be disjoint from this. If it is, the text between the two will be covered by the returned span.
methods.example:
Implementation

FileSpan expand(FileSpan other);

props.name: end
props.desc: The end location of this span, exclusive.

props.name: file
props.desc: The file that this belongs to.

props.name: start
props.desc: The start location of this span.

cn.desc:
A SourceSpan within a SourceFile.

Unlike the base SourceSpan, FileSpan lazily computes its line and column values based on its offset and the contents of file. FileSpan.message is also able to provide more context then SourceSpan.message, and FileSpan.union will return a FileSpan if possible.

A FileSpan can be created using SourceFile.span.

cn.name: source_span.SourceFile

methods.name: SourceFile
methods.desc:
This constructor is deprecated.

Use new SourceFile.fromString instead.
methods.example:
Implementation

@Deprecated("Will be removed in 2.0.0")
SourceFile(String text, {url}) : this.decoded(text.runes, url: url);

methods.name: SourceFile.decoded
methods.desc:
Creates a new source file from a list of decoded code units.

url may be either a String, a Uri, or null.

Currently, if decodedChars contains characters larger than 0xFFFF, they'll be treated as single characters rather than being split into surrogate pairs. This behavior is deprecated. For forwards-compatibility, callers should only pass in characters less than or equal to 0xFFFF.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceFile.decoded(Iterable<int> decodedChars, {url})
    : url = url is String ? Uri.parse(url) : url,
      _decodedChars = new Uint32List.fromList(decodedChars.toList()) {
  for (var i = 0; i < _decodedChars.length; i++) {
    var c = _decodedChars[i];
    if (c == _CR) {
      // Return not followed by newline is treated as a newline
      var j = i + 1;
      if (j >= _decodedChars.length || _decodedChars[j] != _LF) c = _LF;
    }
    if (c == _LF) _lineStarts.add(i + 1);
  }
}

methods.name: SourceFile.fromString
methods.desc:
Creates a new source file from text.

url may be either a String, a Uri, or null.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceFile.fromString(String text, {url})
    : this.decoded(text.codeUnits, url: url);

methods.name: getColumn
methods.desc:
Gets the 0-based column corresponding to offset.

If line is passed, it's assumed to be the line containing offset and is used to more efficiently compute the column.
methods.example:
Implementation

int getColumn(int offset, {int line}) {
  if (offset < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Offset may not be negative, was $offset.");
  } else if (offset > length) {
    throw new RangeError("Offset $offset must be not be greater than the "
        "number of characters in the file, $length.");
  }

  if (line == null) {
    line = getLine(offset);
  } else if (line < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Line may not be negative, was $line.");
  } else if (line >= lines) {
    throw new RangeError("Line $line must be less than the number of "
        "lines in the file, $lines.");
  }

  var lineStart = _lineStarts[line];
  if (lineStart > offset) {
    throw new RangeError("Line $line comes after offset $offset.");
  }

  return offset - lineStart;
}

methods.name: getLine
methods.desc: Gets the 0-based line corresponding to offset.
methods.example:
Implementation

int getLine(int offset) {
  if (offset < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Offset may not be negative, was $offset.");
  } else if (offset > length) {
    throw new RangeError("Offset $offset must not be greater than the number "
        "of characters in the file, $length.");
  }

  if (offset < _lineStarts.first) return -1;
  if (offset >= _lineStarts.last) return _lineStarts.length - 1;

  if (_isNearCachedLine(offset)) return _cachedLine;

  _cachedLine = _binarySearch(offset) - 1;
  return _cachedLine;
}

methods.name: getOffset
methods.desc:
Gets the offset for a line and column.

column defaults to 0.
methods.example:
Implementation

int getOffset(int line, [int column]) {
  if (column == null) column = 0;

  if (line < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Line may not be negative, was $line.");
  } else if (line >= lines) {
    throw new RangeError("Line $line must be less than the number of "
        "lines in the file, $lines.");
  } else if (column < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Column may not be negative, was $column.");
  }

  var result = _lineStarts[line] + column;
  if (result > length ||
      (line + 1 < lines && result >= _lineStarts[line + 1])) {
    throw new RangeError("Line $line doesn't have $column columns.");
  }

  return result;
}

methods.name: getText
methods.desc:
Returns the text of the file from start to end (exclusive).

If end isn't passed, it defaults to the end of the file.
methods.example:
Implementation

String getText(int start, [int end]) =>
    new String.fromCharCodes(_decodedChars.sublist(start, end));

methods.name: location
methods.desc: Returns a location in this at offset.
methods.example:
Implementation

FileLocation location(int offset) => new FileLocation._(this, offset);

methods.name: span
methods.desc:
Returns a span in this from start to end (exclusive).

If end isn't passed, it defaults to the end of the file.
methods.example:
Implementation

FileSpan span(int start, [int end]) {
  if (end == null) end = length;
  return new _FileSpan(this, start, end);
}

props.name: length
props.desc: The length of the file in characters.

props.name: lines
props.desc: The number of lines in the file.

props.name: url
props.desc:
The URL where the source file is located.

This may be null, indicating that the URL is unknown or unavailable.

cn.desc:
A class representing a source file.

This doesn't necessarily have to correspond to a file on disk, just a chunk of text usually with a URL associated with it.

cn.name: source_span.SourceLocation

methods.name: operator ==
methods.desc:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all Objects is to return true if and only if this and other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so whether two objects are equal should only change if at least one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.
methods.example:
Implementation

bool operator ==(other) =>
    other is SourceLocation &&
    sourceUrl == other.sourceUrl &&
    offset == other.offset;

methods.name: SourceLocation
methods.desc:
Creates a new location indicating offset within sourceUrl.

line and column default to assuming the source is a single line. This means that line defaults to 0 and column defaults to offset.

sourceUrl may be either a String, a Uri, or null.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceLocation(int offset, {sourceUrl, int line, int column})
    : sourceUrl = sourceUrl is String ? Uri.parse(sourceUrl) : sourceUrl,
      offset = offset,
      line = line == null ? 0 : line,
      column = column == null ? offset : column {
  if (offset < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Offset may not be negative, was $offset.");
  } else if (line != null && line < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Line may not be negative, was $line.");
  } else if (column != null && column < 0) {
    throw new RangeError("Column may not be negative, was $column.");
  }
}

methods.name: compareTo
methods.desc:
Compares two locations.

other must have the same source URL as this.
methods.example:
Implementation

int compareTo(SourceLocation other) {
  if (sourceUrl != other.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${sourceUrl}\" and "
        "\"${other.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  }
  return offset - other.offset;
}

methods.name: distance
methods.desc:
Returns the distance in characters between this and other.

This always returns a non-negative value.
methods.example:
Implementation

int distance(SourceLocation other) {
  if (sourceUrl != other.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${sourceUrl}\" and "
        "\"${other.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  }
  return (offset - other.offset).abs();
}

methods.name: pointSpan
methods.desc: Returns a span that covers only a single point: this location.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpan pointSpan() => new SourceSpan(this, this, "");

methods.name: toString
methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.example:
Implementation

String toString() => '<$runtimeType: $offset $toolString>';

props.name: column
props.desc: The 0-based column of this location in the source

props.name: hashCode
props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

int get hashCode => sourceUrl.hashCode + offset;

props.name: line
props.desc: The 0-based line of this location in the source.

props.name: offset
props.desc: The 0-based offset of this location in the source.

props.name: sourceUrl
props.desc:
URL of the source containing this location.

This may be null, indicating that the source URL is unknown or unavailable.

props.name: toolString
props.desc:
Returns a representation of this location in the source:line:column format used by text editors.

This prints 1-based lines and columns.
props.example:
Implementation

String get toolString {
  var source = sourceUrl == null ? 'unknown source' : sourceUrl;
  return '$source:${line + 1}:${column + 1}';
}

cn.desc:
A class that describes a single location within a source file.

This class should not be extended. Instead, SourceLocationBase should be extended instead.

cn.name: source_span.SourceLocationBase

methods.name: SourceLocationBase
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceLocationBase(int offset, {sourceUrl, int line, int column})
    : super(offset, sourceUrl: sourceUrl, line: line, column: column);

cn.desc: A base class for source locations with offset, line, and column known at construction time.

methods.name: operator ==
methods.desc:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all Objects is to return true if and only if this and other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so whether two objects are equal should only change if at least one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.
methods.example:
Implementation

bool operator ==(other) =>
    other is SourceLocation &&
    sourceUrl == other.sourceUrl &&
    offset == other.offset;

methods.name: compareTo
methods.desc:
Compares two locations.

other must have the same source URL as this.
methods.example:
Implementation

int compareTo(SourceLocation other) {
  if (sourceUrl != other.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${sourceUrl}\" and "
        "\"${other.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  }
  return offset - other.offset;
}

methods.name: distance
methods.desc:
Returns the distance in characters between this and other.

This always returns a non-negative value.
methods.example:
Implementation

int distance(SourceLocation other) {
  if (sourceUrl != other.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${sourceUrl}\" and "
        "\"${other.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  }
  return (offset - other.offset).abs();
}

methods.name: pointSpan
methods.desc: Returns a span that covers only a single point: this location.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpan pointSpan() => new SourceSpan(this, this, "");

methods.name: toString
methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.example:
Implementation

String toString() => '<$runtimeType: $offset $toolString>';

props.name: hashCode
props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

int get hashCode => sourceUrl.hashCode + offset;

props.name: toolString
props.desc:
Returns a representation of this location in the source:line:column format used by text editors.

This prints 1-based lines and columns.
props.example:
Implementation

String get toolString {
  var source = sourceUrl == null ? 'unknown source' : sourceUrl;
  return '$source:${line + 1}:${column + 1}';
}

cn.name: source_span.SourceSpan

methods.name: SourceSpan
methods.desc:
Creates a new span from start to end (exclusive) containing text.

start and end must have the same source URL and start must come before end. text must have a number of characters equal to the distance between start and end.
methods.example:
Implementation

factory SourceSpan(SourceLocation start, SourceLocation end, String text) =>
    new SourceSpanBase(start, end, text);

methods.name: compareTo
methods.desc:
Compares two spans.

other must have the same source URL as this. This orders spans by start then length.
methods.example:
Implementation

int compareTo(SourceSpan other);

methods.name: highlight
methods.desc:
Prints the text associated with this span in a user-friendly way.

This is identical to message, except that it doesn't print the file name, line number, column number, or message. If length is 0 and this isn't a SourceSpanWithContext, returns an empty string.

color may either be a String, a bool, or null. If it's a string, it indicates an ANSI terminal color escape that should be used to highlight the span's text (for example, "\u001b[31m" will color red). If it's true, it indicates that the text should be highlighted using the default color. If it's false or null, it indicates that the text shouldn't be highlighted.

This uses the full range of Unicode characters to highlight the source span if glyph.ascii is false (the default), but only uses ASCII characters if it's true.
methods.example:
Implementation

String highlight({color});

methods.name: message
methods.desc:
Formats message in a human-friendly way associated with this span.

color may either be a String, a bool, or null. If it's a string, it indicates an ANSI terminal color escape that should be used to highlight the span's text (for example, "\u001b[31m" will color red). If it's true, it indicates that the text should be highlighted using the default color. If it's false or null, it indicates that the text shouldn't be highlighted.

This uses the full range of Unicode characters to highlight the source span if glyph.ascii is false (the default), but only uses ASCII characters if it's true.
methods.example:
Implementation

String message(String message, {color});

methods.name: union
methods.desc:
Creates a new span that's the union of this and other.

The two spans must have the same source URL and may not be disjoint. text is computed by combining this.text and other.text.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpan union(SourceSpan other);

props.name: end
props.desc: The end location of this span, exclusive.

props.name: length
props.desc: The length of this span, in characters.

props.name: sourceUrl
props.desc:
The URL of the source (typically a file) of this span.

This may be null, indicating that the source URL is unknown or unavailable.

props.name: start
props.desc: The start location of this span.

props.name: text
props.desc: The source text for this span.

cn.desc: A class that describes a segment of source text.

cn.name: source_span.SourceSpanBase

methods.name: SourceSpanBase
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpanBase(this.start, this.end, this.text) {
  if (end.sourceUrl != start.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${start.sourceUrl}\" and "
        " \"${end.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  } else if (end.offset < start.offset) {
    throw new ArgumentError('End $end must come after start $start.');
  } else if (text.length != start.distance(end)) {
    throw new ArgumentError('Text "$text" must be ${start.distance(end)} '
        'characters long.');
  }
}

props.name: end
props.desc: The end location of this span, exclusive.

props.name: start
props.desc: The start location of this span.

props.name: text
props.desc: The source text for this span.

cn.desc: A base class for source spans with start, end, and text known at construction time.

cn.name: source_span.SourceSpanException

methods.name: SourceSpanException
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpanException(this._message, this._span);

methods.name: toString
methods.desc:
Returns a string representation of this.

color may either be a String, a bool, or null. If it's a string, it indicates an ANSII terminal color escape that should be used to highlight the span's text. If it's true, it indicates that the text should be highlighted using the default color. If it's false or null, it indicates that the text shouldn't be highlighted.
methods.example:
Implementation

String toString({color}) {
  if (span == null) return message;
  return "Error on " + span.message(message, color: color);
}

props.name: message
props.desc: A message describing the exception.

props.name: span
props.desc:
The span associated with this exception.

This may be null if the source location can't be determined.

cn.desc: A class for exceptions that have source span information attached.

methods.name: SourceSpanFormatException
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpanFormatException(String message, SourceSpan span, [this._source])
    : super(message, span);

props.name: offset
props.desc:
The offset in source where the error was detected.

A zero-based offset into the source that marks the format error causing this exception to be created. If source is a string, this should be a string index in the range 0 <= offset <= source.length.

If input is a string, the toString method may represent this offset as a line and character position. The offset should be inside the string, or at the end of the string.

May be omitted. If present, source should also be present if possible.
props.example:
Implementation

int get offset => span == null ? null : span.start.offset;

props.name: source
props.desc:
The actual source input which caused the error.

This is usually a String, but can be other types too. If it is a string, parts of it may be included in the toString message.

The source is null if omitted or unknown.

cn.name: source_span.SourceSpanMixin

methods.name: operator ==
methods.desc:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all Objects is to return true if and only if this and other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so whether two objects are equal should only change if at least one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.
methods.example:
Implementation

bool operator ==(other) =>
    other is SourceSpan && start == other.start && end == other.end;

methods.name: compareTo
methods.desc:
Compares two spans.

other must have the same source URL as this. This orders spans by start then length.
methods.example:
Implementation

int compareTo(SourceSpan other) {
  var result = start.compareTo(other.start);
  return result == 0 ? end.compareTo(other.end) : result;
}

methods.name: highlight
methods.desc:
Prints the text associated with this span in a user-friendly way.

This is identical to message, except that it doesn't print the file name, line number, column number, or message. If length is 0 and this isn't a SourceSpanWithContext, returns an empty string.

color may either be a String, a bool, or null. If it's a string, it indicates an ANSI terminal color escape that should be used to highlight the span's text (for example, "\u001b[31m" will color red). If it's true, it indicates that the text should be highlighted using the default color. If it's false or null, it indicates that the text shouldn't be highlighted.

This uses the full range of Unicode characters to highlight the source span if glyph.ascii is false (the default), but only uses ASCII characters if it's true.
methods.example:
Implementation

String highlight({color}) {
  if (this is! SourceSpanWithContext && this.length == 0) return "";
  return new Highlighter(this, color: color).highlight();
}

methods.name: message
methods.desc:
Formats message in a human-friendly way associated with this span.

color may either be a String, a bool, or null. If it's a string, it indicates an ANSI terminal color escape that should be used to highlight the span's text (for example, "\u001b[31m" will color red). If it's true, it indicates that the text should be highlighted using the default color. If it's false or null, it indicates that the text shouldn't be highlighted.

This uses the full range of Unicode characters to highlight the source span if glyph.ascii is false (the default), but only uses ASCII characters if it's true.
methods.example:
Implementation

String message(String message, {color}) {
  var buffer = new StringBuffer();
  buffer.write('line ${start.line + 1}, column ${start.column + 1}');
  if (sourceUrl != null) buffer.write(' of ${p.prettyUri(sourceUrl)}');
  buffer.write(': $message');

  var highlight = this.highlight(color: color);
  if (!highlight.isEmpty) {
    buffer.writeln();
    buffer.write(highlight);
  }

  return buffer.toString();
}

methods.name: toString
methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.example:
Implementation

String toString() => '<$runtimeType: from $start to $end "$text">';

methods.name: union
methods.desc:
Creates a new span that's the union of this and other.

The two spans must have the same source URL and may not be disjoint. text is computed by combining this.text and other.text.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpan union(SourceSpan other) {
  if (sourceUrl != other.sourceUrl) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Source URLs \"${sourceUrl}\" and "
        " \"${other.sourceUrl}\" don't match.");
  }

  var start = min(this.start, other.start);
  var end = max(this.end, other.end);
  var beginSpan = start == this.start ? this : other;
  var endSpan = end == this.end ? this : other;

  if (beginSpan.end.compareTo(endSpan.start) < 0) {
    throw new ArgumentError("Spans $this and $other are disjoint.");
  }

  var text = beginSpan.text +
      endSpan.text.substring(beginSpan.end.distance(endSpan.start));
  return new SourceSpan(start, end, text);
}

props.name: hashCode
props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

int get hashCode => start.hashCode + (31 * end.hashCode);

props.name: length
props.desc: The length of this span, in characters.
props.example:
Implementation

int get length => end.offset - start.offset;

props.name: sourceUrl
props.desc:
The URL of the source (typically a file) of this span.

This may be null, indicating that the source URL is unknown or unavailable.

cn.desc:
A mixin for easily implementing SourceSpan.

This implements the SourceSpan methods in terms of start, end, and text. This assumes that start and end have the same source URL, that start comes before end, and that text has a number of characters equal to the distance between start and end.

cn.name: source_span.SourceSpanWithContext

methods.name: SourceSpanWithContext
methods.desc:
Creates a new span from start to end (exclusive) containing text, in the given context.

start and end must have the same source URL and start must come before end. text must have a number of characters equal to the distance between start and end. context must contain text, and text should start at start.column from the beginning of a line in context.
methods.example:
Implementation

SourceSpanWithContext(
    SourceLocation start, SourceLocation end, String text, this._context)
    : super(start, end, text) {
  if (!context.contains(text)) {
    throw new ArgumentError(
        'The context line "$context" must contain "$text".');
  }

  if (findLineStart(context, text, start.column) == null) {
    throw new ArgumentError('The span text "$text" must start at '
        'column ${start.column + 1} in a line within "$context".');
  }
}

props.name: context
props.desc: Text around the span, which includes the line containing this span.

cn.desc: A class that describes a segment of source text with additional context.
